Award.AwardTitle: RET Site: WySTACK - Supporting Teachers And Computing Knowledge

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
As the sole four-year institution in the state of Wyoming, the University of Wyoming (UW) will partner with twelve school districts, Northwest Community College faculty, and several industry partners to create a completely virtual RET site. This virtual approach mirrors the realities of present-day collaborative research and enables the researchers and educators an opportunity to identify limitations, needs, and requirements for rural-based engagement in authentic computer science research. Pandemic-induced infrastructure modifications coupled with UW’s success in hosting virtual teacher professional development activities validate the feasibility of UW offering a virtual research experience. The site will recruit 36 high school STEM teachers and two community college faculty members to virtually participate in research with four CS faculty working on a diverse set of projects which all maintain a common thread of data science–either within Machine Learning, Cybersecurity, Virtual/Augmented Reality, or High Performance Computing. The project builds upon existing work by the state to develop a community of practice among industry, academic, and community partners and has already provided authentic-inquiry experiences to hundreds of educators allowing them to develop useable curricular products in their classrooms.

The University of Wyoming in collaboration with twelve Wyoming school districts, Northwest (Community) College, and business/industry partners will host a new RET Site to engage 36 high school teachers and two community college faculty over a 3-year period. STEM teacher participants will engage in a six-week authentic summer virtual research experience focused on addressing rural issues through authentic applications and societal impacts of advanced computing research with academic year follow-up sessions. Through a common thread of data science, specific project research areas include 1) AI and high-performance computing, 2) Machine learning for security,3) Virtual and augmented reality, and 4) Attacking and creating secure and resilient rural infrastructure. The educators will then translate their research experiences and newly gained content knowledge into their classrooms through the creation and dissemination of course materials and reusable curricular modules developed in collaboration with the research team and community college participants. These engagements will contribute to the development and support of a larger community of practice, WyCS, that is coalescing in Wyoming between a variety of industry, academic, and community partners (uwyo.edu/wycs).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

ProgramReference.Text: RET SITE-Res Exp for Tchr Site

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report: WySTACK ​

Introduction The Wyoming Supporting Teachers and Computational Knowledge (WySTACK) project, conducted from 2021 to 2024, aimed to enhance computer science education by providing research experiences to high school STEM teachers and community college faculty. ​ Funded by the National Science Foundation (NSF), the project sought to integrate computer science into existing coursework, thereby enriching the educational landscape and preparing students for a technology-driven future. ​

Intellectual Merit The WySTACK project significantly advanced the participants' knowledge and teaching capabilities in computer science. ​ Key outcomes include:

  1. Increased Content Knowledge:

    • Participants demonstrated substantial gains in their understanding of computer science concepts. ​ Surveys showed improved correct responses on knowledge items from pre- to post-training and sustained over time. ​
    • Specific areas of improvement included understanding computer science standards and everyday computer science topics. ​

  2. Enhanced Self-Efficacy and Attitudes:

    • Participants reported increased confidence and positive attitudes towards computer science and research. ​ Statistical analyses confirmed significant improvements in self-efficacy and attitudes, indicating a stronger foundation for teaching these subjects. ​

  3. Effective Integration of Computer Science Content:

    • Most participants successfully incorporated computer science into their existing coursework. ​ Despite some technological access issues, 25 out of 26 participants who completed the follow-up survey integrated computer science content and planned to continue doing so. ​

Broader Impacts The WySTACK project had a profound impact on both educators and students, contributing to the broader educational and societal goals:

  1. Improved Teaching Practices:

    • The project equipped educators with the skills and confidence to integrate computer science into their lessons, fostering a more interdisciplinary approach to teaching. ​ This not only enhanced the quality of education but also made learning more engaging for students. ​

  2. Increased Student Engagement:

    • By incorporating computer science into various subjects, educators were able to spark students' interest in technology and computational thinking. ​ This is crucial for preparing students for future careers in a technology-driven world. ​

  3. Satisfaction with Mentorship and Support:

    • Participants expressed high satisfaction with the support from faculty-research mentors and graduate students. ​ This mentorship was instrumental in helping educators effectively integrate computer science into their teaching. ​

  4. Successful Virtual Implementation:

    • The virtual format of the summer training was well-received, demonstrating that high-quality professional development can be delivered remotely. ​ This has implications for expanding access to similar programs in the future.

Conclusion The WySTACK project successfully increased participants' computer science knowledge, improved their teaching efficacy, and facilitated the integration of computer science into their coursework. ​ These outcomes not only enhanced the professional capabilities of educators but also enriched the educational experiences of their students. ​ By addressing both the intellectual merit and broader impacts, the WySTACK project has made a significant contribution to advancing computer science education and preparing students for a future where technology plays a central role. ​

 


Last Modified: 10/30/2024
Modified by: Mike Borowczak
